reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.
The reading is the same like お願いします. Hopefully you're able to read that by now so you're able to read this too.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Now how about you "<reading>han</reading>d" me another bowl of rice?

The reading is different from what you learned with the kanji. Remember the word 竹? It has the same reading as this. Just think of everyone measuring the heights of things with <reading>bamboo</reading> (たけ) poles with markers on them. Okay, this one is 5 bamboo poles high!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji), you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading, which you didn't learn with the kanji. Here's a mnemonic to help you:

You're stuck on a huge mountain, and the only way <vocabulary>to go down</vocabulary> is by using your <reading>o</reading>bi (お). So you'll have <vocabulary>to descend</vocabulary> this entire mountain with nothing but your obi, acting as a rope. Good luck!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just keep in mind that the reading of 不 changes from ふ to ぶ. If you're clumsy you'll get a lot of <reading>boo</reading>-boos (ぶ), get it?
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You hopefully learned the on'yomi for 乗 with the word 乗馬, but here's a mnemonic to help you just in case:

You notice a <vocabulary>passenger</vocabulary> getting on at your stop. Who is it? The distinct smell of barn animals and manure gives it away immediately: it’s <reading>Joe</reading> (じょう), the farmhand!

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 乗, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Know who loves <vocabulary>horseback riding</vocabulary>? That's right, <reading>Joe</reading> (じょう) the farmhand. It makes sense, with him being a farmhand and all.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. So, if you know 人's reading as a vocab word and 殺す's reading, you should be able to read this word. Just note that ころし goes to ごろし due to rendaku.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just be aware that the は at the end is actually the particle は so it's pronounced like わ.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You go up to <vocabulary>Buddha</vocabulary>. You want to rub his head for good luck, because that's what you hear is good to do. Right before you touch him, he backs off and says, "Whoa! I'm <reading>hot, okay</reading>?" (ほとけ). You touch him and it burns your hand clean off. 

Imagine saying "hot, okay?" in a strange accent to help you to remember.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that 仏 gets changed to ぶっ for this one.

When a vocab word is a single kanji with no okurigana, it takes the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this one yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember: 

When the <vocabulary>go-between</vocabulary> gets back and is about to tell you everything the other group said, it takes him <reading>two ta</reading>kes (つて) to get it all right. The other group had a lot to say and he had trouble getting it all on the first take, but he totally nailed it on the second.

Little side note: this word is actually more common in katakana, as in ツテ, or hiragana, as in つて. Still, you might see it in kanji too, and it's good if you can read it!

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since the さく reading of 作 becomes さっ here, we've made a mnemonic for you to remember this reading:

<vocabulary>Writer</vocabulary>s love <reading>soccer</reading> (さっか). In fact, playing soccer is how they get their inspiration. Try playing some soccer, maybe you'll become a <vocabulary>creator</vocabulary> too!
The reading for 信 is しん no matter what! See, if you believe, good things will happen. You should be able to read this.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note that しん changes to じん.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

meanings.meaning: Something Heard For The First Time

reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses kun'yomi instead of on'yomi readings, because 初 behaves more like a prefix here. You already know how to read 耳, but you haven't learned the kun'yomi for 初 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:

Whatever it is, this <vocabulary>something heard for the first time</vocabulary>, be sure to hold onto your <reading>hats</reading> (はつ)! It's going to be something big, and I'm pretty sure it's going to be <vocabulary>news</vocabulary> to me, too.

allMeanings.meaning: Something Heard For The First Time

reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji!
If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
You should know how to read both 受ける and 入れる, so you should be good to go!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word that uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The reading you learned with the kanji is the same as this one.
The reading is the one you learned with the kanji. How strange! Or not.

This word uses the kun'yomi, which you didn't learn with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you out.

You want <vocabulary>to change something</vocabulary> about your <reading>ca</reading>r (か) but you don't quite know what yet. Maybe your car should have a really cool feature, like a hot tub or a giant screen. Try to think of the silliest ways you could change your car.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be a kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this one yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

If you're going <vocabulary>to disconnect something</vocabulary>, it <reading>has</reading> (はず) to be the right thing! Don't go disconnecting the wrong plug, you'll cause no end of trouble!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Think about your <vocabulary>husband</vocabulary> even if you don't have one. What's his name? It's <reading>Otto</reading> (おっと), and he's always leaving you at home because he's working at the <reading>auto</reading> (おっと) shop.

The reading is a strange one, different from anything you've learned, kanji on'yomi or vocab kun'yomi. The reading is この, so think of this: 

What’s something easy <vocabulary>to be fond of</vocabulary>? <reading>子</reading>? <reading>No</reading> (この), not for you. You’re always saying “子? No!” Most people are fond of kids, at least their own, but not you. Noisy, germy, needy 子? No, no thank you!
The reading is the vocab word 子 (こ) and the reading for cat (ねこ).
The reading is the same as the kanji too! You must have been praying to the kanji Gods at the local お寺.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, so you can read this one!

The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. You can return home happily, knowing how to read this word! 

This word has a pair verb though, so you'll want to remember the る ending. Just imagine how <reading>ru</reading>de (る) it is when someone goes home without saying goodbye. The nerve!
The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. In fact, this kanji's on'yomi AND kun'yomi are しき, so you can never go wrong.
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!
The reading comes from the one you learned with the kanji.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You do your <vocabulary>technique</vocabulary> on a bad guy, coming at you. You flip him over and knock him out. He <reading>was</reading> (わざ) a threat, but now he's not. You look closer at the bad guy. Turns out it's <reading>Woz</reading>, the Apple Co-founder. He was just trying to hand you an iPhone12, not grab your wrist. Whoops!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

The readings come from the individual vocab readings, 指 and 輪. In English we don't distinguish some other ring from a "finger ring" but in Japanese, you can think of this as two separate words coming together to form one word, which is why it uses the kun'yomi vocab readings like this. So, if you know the individual words, you should be able to figure out this word is read as <reading>ゆびわ</reading>.
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Everything in your room has finally been <vocabulary>put in order</vocabulary>. Just as you finish, you hear a crash and turn to see your dog has jumped up onto your desk. "<reading>Toto no</reading> (ととの)!" you yell as he knocks everything over. Guess you have  <vocabulary>to arrange</vocabulary>  it all over again. Dammit Toto.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The ほう changes to ぽう.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Ah, the beauty of spring! Err... はる, I mean.
The reading for 春 is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. The 休み part is the same as the vocab word 休み, which hopefully you can read! If you know those readings, you can read this too.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note that さく changes to さっ as many K-column sounds do in situations like this.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Oof. The reading for this word makes no sense. You'll have to forget everything you've learned about the readings of the kanji and just go straight up mnemonic for the word on its own. Okay. Think about what you did yesterday, all day. You played <reading>keno</reading> (きのう), gambling away your grandmother's money. Yesterday was the worst day ever because you lost everything playing Keno. Today is different, not like yesterday, right?
The reading for this word is the same as the kanji it comes from, so you should be able to read it!
The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them already, so you should be able to read this too!

The reading for this is pretty weird. 計 is all nice and normal, but 時 is と for some reason. It probably is coming from the vocab word 時 (とき), is my guess. But even if it is, it's shortened, making it a step more complicated. Maybe it's just better to imagine that your <vocabulary>watch</vocabulary> is a walky <reading>talky</reading> (とけい) and run with that?
The reading here is the same as the kanji reading!
This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
The reading you learned with the kanji is the one you use here. One of those words where the kun'yomi's going to be more useful.
The reading comes from 暗記. It also is the reading you learned with the kanji too.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The reading is just the reading you learned with the kanji. The second one is ざま however, which plays right into the "various" meaning of the word. There's even various ways to read さま in this word!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The reading for this word is the same as the kanji's reading.
The reading is the same as the kanji it comes from. The ガス is of course "gas."
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. If you remember the kanji reading you'll have no problem with this word.
The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, making this <reading>あさ</reading>い.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Neko neko neko! Kawaiiiii.

You didn't learn this reading for 由 so here's a mnemonic to help you:

The best way to get close to the <vocabulary>origin</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>source</vocabulary> of something is to move into a <reading>yu</reading>rt (ゆ). Yurts are easy to move around, so you can always get close to the source, wherever that may be.

There's reason <vocabulary>to doubt</vocabulary> that you can teach an <reading>u</reading>ni <reading>Taga</reading>log (うたが), but once you try, it's actually not that hard. They're very good listeners after all.

The readings are the kun'yomi readings. For 手, that's no problem for you. For 相, that's more of an issue since you learned the on'yomi reading for it. Think of it this way: 

Your partner wouldn't be your partner without you. Your partner is: <reading>I</reading> (あい) and you. Remember that as you gaze into your partner's eyes. "I and you."
The readings are the readings you learned with the kanji. If one thing is lucky, it's probably that.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, <reading>あき</reading>.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The reading comes from the kanji as well as from the vocab word 練習. You should be able to read this!

The reading for this makes no sense at all. You'll have to learn it straight up, that is, unless you know the word おいしい already, which many people do as it's used in every other sentence in every Japanese variety show. If you don't know this word already, just think of yourself eating something <vocabulary>delicious</vocabulary>. It's so delicious it makes you mad, I have no idea why. You yell at the chef: "<reading>OI</reading> (おい). OI! WHY IS THIS SO DELICIOUS????"
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

How much 自信 do you have that you know how to read this word already? I bet you have some, at least! This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meanings.meaning: To Show Someone What One Can Do

reading_mnemonic: The readings are from the words 見 and 返す put together.

allMeanings.meaning: To Show Someone What One Can Do

reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The reading for 画 is the secondary reading though (かく), so take note of that.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The reading for 輪 is the kun'yomi vocab reading, which is わ, making this word <reading>わ</reading>ゴム.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading consists of the readings of 食べる and 放題. If you know those you should be able to read this too.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're eating a <vocabulary>meal</vocabulary>... MMmm, delicious! What are you eating? Well, it's a <reading>Mesh</reading> (めし) net. Taste the mesh net. It tastes terrible. This is a bad meal. Feel it in your mouth. It's weird and meshy.
The reading comes from the word 放題 (ほうだい) and 飲む (のむ). So long as you know those vocab words, you'll be able to read this one as well.
